For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. neighboring nodes share heralded optical Bell pairs, and a central entanglement\u2010swapping station fuses the two links into a long\u2010distance entangled link between A and C.\n  Step 2: Compare to past experiments:\n    a) is structurally similar to standard entanglement swapping but now explicitly involves transducers linking to superconducting qubits\u2014novel hybrid aspect.\n    b) is a teleportation network (never before done in Pytheus examples) rather than state\u2010generation; no direct analog in the explored list.\n    c) is a straightforward multi\u2010swap extension of (a); less novel than (b).\n  Step 3: Pick (b), the teleportation channel, because it focuses on the network transformation (teleportation) rather than state\u2010generation, highlights a clear hybrid transduction element, and can be generalized to repeater chains.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it is the first Pytheus\u2010style proposal to implement an end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation channel between two solid\u2010state nodes (superconducting qubits) mediated by quantum transducers and linear optics, rather than merely generating entangled states.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It only requires single\u2010photon sources (to emulate the transduced qubit carriers and the Bell pair source) and linear\u2010optics components for the Bell measurement.\n    \u2022 No cavities or dynamic feedback control are needed\u2014Pytheus can optimize the beam\u2010splitter network and detector placement to realize the required Bell projection.\n    \u2022 The abstract target is a teleportation \u201cchannel\u201d encoded as perfect correlations between the sender\u2019s input basis and the receiver\u2019s output basis, which Pytheus can handle via its in_nodes/out_nodes mechanism and a simple two\u2010bit target_quantum list.\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nExplanation:\nIn this proposal, we implement quantum teleportation of an arbitrary superconducting\u2010qubit state from node A to node B using quantum transduction and linear optics.  \n1. Node A houses a superconducting qubit whose state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 (unknown superposition of \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9) is transduced into a photonic qubit (time\u2010bin or dual\u2010rail) via a quantum transducer.  \n2. Node B also has a transducer coupled to a superconducting qubit initially prepared in one arm of an optical Bell pair; the other photon of that pair will later be used in the Bell measurement.  \n3. The flying photonic qubit from A and one photon of the Bell pair from B are routed to a central linear\u2010optics station, where a Bell\u2010state analyzer (beam splitters + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors) performs a joint measurement. Two ancillary detectors register a successful Bell outcome.  \n4. Upon heralding, classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus\u2019s scope) directs a Pauli correction on superconducting qubit B, completing teleportation.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources: [S_trans_A] [S_Bell1] [S_Bell2]  \noptical network: [beam splitters, phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla1][ancilla2] [out_\u03c8]  \n\nHere [out_\u03c8] feeds the teleported qubit back into superconducting qubit B (via its transducer in reverse).  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 Extend to repeater chains by adding intermediate transducers and swapping stations between nodes.  \n\u2022 Replace the two-photon Bell pair source at B with a scalable multi-photon resource for cluster-state\u2013based teleportation.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation between superconducting qubits via quantum transduction and linear\u2010optics Bell measurement',  \n 'foldername': 'TransducerTeleport',  \n 'num_anc': 2,  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1],        # 0=transduced \u03c8 from A, 1=one photon of Bell pair from B  \n 'out_nodes': [2],         # teleported \u03c8 arrives here  \n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # perfect correlation between input bit and output bit  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,2]], # no direct source\u2010to\u2010output link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'number_resolving': True,  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1], # treat both transduced qubit and Bell\u2010pair photon as single\u2010photon sources  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops in Pytheus; only linear optics, probabilistic sources, and photon detection."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. The scheme encodes the d=3 complex phase map \u03c9^{ij} (with \u03c9\u2009=\u2009e^{2\u03c0i/3}) on the basis states |i\u27e9\u2090|j\u27e9\u1d66 without any direct A\u2013B coupling, realizing a genuine higher-dimensional logical primitive in the PytHeus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n\u201cSingle-Shot Nonlocal String-Order Correlator Network via Linear-Optical Entanglement Swapping\u201d\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe implement the Nonlocal String-Order Correlator Network, a purely linear-optical, non-factorizable tensor-network contraction that directly measures the MPS string-order operator \u27e8\u03c8|Z\u2081X\u2082\u2026X\u2099\u208b\u2081Z\u2099|\u03c8\u27e9 in one heralded entanglement-swapping step. In this purely passive linear-optical protocol, an arbitrary qubit encoded in node A\u2019s photonic Bell pair is heraldedly transferred onto node C\u2019s matter qubit using only fixed beam splitters, phase shifters, vacuum ancillas, and number-resolving detectors, with no active tuning or feedback required.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. Node A houses a superconducting qubit whose state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 (unknown superposition of \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9) is transduced into a photonic qubit (time\u2010bin or dual\u2010rail) via a quantum transducer.  \n2. Node B also has a transducer coupled to a superconducting qubit initially prepared in one arm of an optical Bell pair; the other photon of that pair will later be used in the Bell measurement.  \n3. The flying photonic qubit from A and one photon of the Bell pair from B are routed to a central linear\u2010optics station, where a Bell\u2010state analyzer (beam splitters + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors) performs a joint measurement. Two ancillary detectors register a successful Bell outcome.  \n4. Upon heralding, classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus\u2019s scope) directs a Pauli correction on superconducting qubit B, completing teleportation.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources: [S_trans_A] [S_Bell1] [S_Bell2]  \noptical network: [beam splitters, phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla1][ancilla2] [out_\u03c8]  \n\nHere [out_\u03c8] feeds the teleported qubit back into superconducting qubit B (via its transducer in reverse).  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 Extend to repeater chains by adding intermediate transducers and swapping stations between nodes.  \n\u2022 Replace the two-photon Bell pair source at B with a scalable multi-photon resource for cluster-state\u2013based teleportation.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation between superconducting qubits via quantum transduction and linear\u2010optics Bell measurement',  \n 'foldername': 'TransducerTeleport',  \n 'num_anc': 2,  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1],        # 0=transduced \u03c8 from A, 1=one photon of Bell pair from B  \n 'out_nodes': [2],         # teleported \u03c8 arrives here  \n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # perfect correlation between input bit and output bit  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,2]], # no direct source\u2010to\u2010output link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'number_resolving': True,  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1], # treat both transduced qubit and Bell\u2010pair photon as single\u2010photon sources  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops in Pytheus; only linear optics, probabilistic sources, and photon detection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposal is essentially the standard quantum teleportation primitive\u2014using one Bell pair and a Bell-state measurement\u2014to transfer an arbitrary qubit state, here simply extended via a quantum transducer to superconducting qubits. While interfacing superconducting and photonic platforms is technologically important, the linear\u2010optical network itself remains the classic teleportation scheme with nothing fundamentally new in the measurement or network topology. This does not meet our bar for a novel PRL\u2010worthy quantum\u2010optics experiment.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The idea must go beyond straightforward teleportation; you need to introduce a genuinely new network primitive or measurement that isn\u2019t already just the standard Bell\u2010swap/teleport protocol. Consider adding nontrivial topological routing, higher\u2010dimensional entanglement swapping, multi\u2010node repeater features, or leveraging unique properties of the transducer in the network itself."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Node B also has a transducer coupled to a superconducting qubit initially prepared in one arm of an optical Bell pair; the other photon of that pair will later be used in the Bell measurement.  \n3. Two ancillary detectors register a successful Bell outcome.  \n4. (Too close to textbook teleportation.)\n    b) A repeater segment: two entanglement\u2010swapping stations between three superconducting nodes. (Structurally like existing multi\u2010swap examples.)\n    c) A \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a single joint linear\u2010optics measurement to teleport an unknown qubit from A onto either B or C, purely by heralding patterns\u2014no active switching, just post\u2010selection.  \n  Step 2: Novelty/obstacles:\n    a) Already textbook; little new network primitive.  \n    b) Already covered by multi\u2010swap examples.  \n    c) Novel: conditional routing of a qubit to different receivers via measurement\u2010induced network branching. Pytheus can optimize a fixed multiport interferometer plus detectors; no feedback required.  \n  Step 3: Pick (c), the teleportation router.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it realizes a new quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014measurement\u2010induced routing of a quantum state to one of multiple solid\u2010state nodes\u2014using transduction plus linear optics, without dynamic switches.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since it only uses single\u2010photon sources (the two transducers and two Bell\u2010pair sources), a static multiport interferometer, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors; no cavities or feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nExplanation:\nWe propose a \u201cquantum teleportation router\u201d linking three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes (A, B, C) via quantum transduction and a single linear\u2010optics measurement. An unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 on A is mapped to a photonic qubit via its transducer (source S_A). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources at B and C emit optical Bell pairs (S_B and S_C). Half of each Bell pair remains at the respective node as the target memory; the other halves are sent to a central multiport interferometer. In that interferometer the photon from A and the two \u201cflying\u201d Bell photons are mixed in a fixed three\u2010input linear\u2010optics network. Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record one of two distinct heralding patterns\u2014pattern P_B heralds teleportation of \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 onto B\u2019s retained photon, pattern P_C heralds teleportation onto C\u2019s retained photon. No active switching is required; the routing choice is made by post\u2010selection.  \n\nVisualization (sources send photons downwards):\nsources:   [S_A]   [S_B]   [S_C]  \nnetwork:   [three\u2010input beam splitters + phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla detectors P1,P2,P3]  \nmemories:  [qubit B]  [qubit C]  \n\nWhen the detectors click in pattern P_B (e.g. clicks on D1+D2), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at B\u2019s memory; if they click in P_C (D2+D3), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at C\u2019s memory.  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N receivers by adding N Bell sources and routing via an N+1\u2010port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use delayed\u2010choice routing by deferring which heralding pattern is selected for key\u2010agreement or multi\u2010party protocols.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation router: A\u2192{B or C} via transducers & static linear optics',  \n 'foldername': 'TeleportationRouter',  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1,2],      # 0=S_A, 1=S_B(idler), 2=S_C(idler)  \n 'num_anc': 3,                    # three ancilla detectors in the multiport  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1,2],             # 0=A\u2019s photon; 1,2=Bell photons sent for measurement  \n 'out_nodes': [3,4],              # 3=B\u2019s retained photon; 4=C\u2019s retained photon  \n 'target_quantum': ['000','100','011','111'],  \n   # Interpret '000' & '100' as patterns P_B routing 0\u2192B, '011'/'111' as P_C routing to C  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,3],[0,4]],  \n   # no direct source\u2010to\u2010memory link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops\u2014only static linear optics, probabilistic sources, and post\u2010selected heralding."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Explanation:\nIn this proposal, we implement quantum teleportation of an arbitrary superconducting\u2010qubit state from node A to node B using quantum transduction and linear optics.  \n1. Node A houses a superconducting qubit whose state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 (unknown superposition of \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9) is transduced into a photonic qubit (time\u2010bin or dual\u2010rail) via a quantum transducer.  \n2. Node B also has a transducer coupled to a superconducting qubit initially prepared in one arm of an optical Bell pair; the other photon of that pair will later be used in the Bell measurement.  \n3. The flying photonic qubit from A and one photon of the Bell pair from B are routed to a central linear\u2010optics station, where a Bell\u2010state analyzer (beam splitters + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors) performs a joint measurement. Two ancillary detectors register a successful Bell outcome.  \n4. Upon heralding, classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus\u2019s scope) directs a Pauli correction on superconducting qubit B, completing teleportation.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources: [S_trans_A] [S_Bell1] [S_Bell2]  \noptical network: [beam splitters, phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla1][ancilla2] [out_\u03c8]  \n\nHere [out_\u03c8] feeds the teleported qubit back into superconducting qubit B (via its transducer in reverse).  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 Extend to repeater chains by adding intermediate transducers and swapping stations between nodes.  \n\u2022 Replace the two-photon Bell pair source at B with a scalable multi-photon resource for cluster-state\u2013based teleportation.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation between superconducting qubits via quantum transduction and linear\u2010optics Bell measurement',  \n 'foldername': 'TransducerTeleport',  \n 'num_anc': 2,  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1],        # 0=transduced \u03c8 from A, 1=one photon of Bell pair from B  \n 'out_nodes': [2],         # teleported \u03c8 arrives here  \n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # perfect correlation between input bit and output bit  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,2]], # no direct source\u2010to\u2010output link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'number_resolving': True,  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1], # treat both transduced qubit and Bell\u2010pair photon as single\u2010photon sources  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops in Pytheus; only linear optics, probabilistic sources, and photon detection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal is essentially the standard quantum teleportation primitive\u2014using one Bell pair and a Bell-state measurement\u2014to transfer an arbitrary qubit state, here simply extended via a quantum transducer to superconducting qubits. While interfacing superconducting and photonic platforms is technologically important, the linear\u2010optical network itself remains the classic teleportation scheme with nothing fundamentally new in the measurement or network topology. This does not meet our bar for a novel PRL\u2010worthy quantum\u2010optics experiment.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The idea must go beyond straightforward teleportation; you need to introduce a genuinely new network primitive or measurement that isn\u2019t already just the standard Bell\u2010swap/teleport protocol. Consider adding nontrivial topological routing, higher\u2010dimensional entanglement swapping, multi\u2010node repeater features, or leveraging unique properties of the transducer in the network itself.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Explanation:\nWe propose a \u201cquantum teleportation router\u201d linking three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes (A, B, C) via quantum transduction and a single linear\u2010optics measurement. An unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 on A is mapped to a photonic qubit via its transducer (source S_A). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources at B and C emit optical Bell pairs (S_B and S_C). Half of each Bell pair remains at the respective node as the target memory; the other halves are sent to a central multiport interferometer. In that interferometer the photon from A and the two \u201cflying\u201d Bell photons are mixed in a fixed three\u2010input linear\u2010optics network. Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record one of two distinct heralding patterns\u2014pattern P_B heralds teleportation of \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 onto B\u2019s retained photon, pattern P_C heralds teleportation onto C\u2019s retained photon. No active switching is required; the routing choice is made by post\u2010selection.  \n\nVisualization (sources send photons downwards):\nsources:   [S_A]   [S_B]   [S_C]  \nnetwork:   [three\u2010input beam splitters + phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla detectors P1,P2,P3]  \nmemories:  [qubit B]  [qubit C]  \n\nWhen the detectors click in pattern P_B (e.g. clicks on D1+D2), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at B\u2019s memory; if they click in P_C (D2+D3), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at C\u2019s memory.  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N receivers by adding N Bell sources and routing via an N+1\u2010port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use delayed\u2010choice routing by deferring which heralding pattern is selected for key\u2010agreement or multi\u2010party protocols.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation router: A\u2192{B or C} via transducers & static linear optics',  \n 'foldername': 'TeleportationRouter',  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1,2],      # 0=S_A, 1=S_B(idler), 2=S_C(idler)  \n 'num_anc': 3,                    # three ancilla detectors in the multiport  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1,2],             # 0=A\u2019s photon; 1,2=Bell photons sent for measurement  \n 'out_nodes': [3,4],              # 3=B\u2019s retained photon; 4=C\u2019s retained photon  \n 'target_quantum': ['000','100','011','111'],  \n   # Interpret '000' & '100' as patterns P_B routing 0\u2192B, '011'/'111' as P_C routing to C  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,3],[0,4]],  \n   # no direct source\u2010to\u2010memory link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops\u2014only static linear optics, probabilistic sources, and post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This \u201cteleportation router\u201d is essentially the same passive, post\u2010selected dual\u2010destination teleportation primitive already proposed in the ensemble (e.g. \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch\u201d and \u201cProgrammable Photonic Teleportation Router for Three Qubits\u201d), merely dressed up with superconducting-to-photon transducers. It does not introduce a new measurement primitive or network topology beyond standard Bell-swap routing.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel, you must go beyond straightforward teleportation routing. Propose a genuinely new multi-node primitive (e.g. non-trivial interference of multiple swap orders, programmable higher-dimensional routing, indefinite causal structures, etc.) or leverage unique transducer physics as an integral network element rather than just a state interface."
}
{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Node A houses a superconducting qubit whose state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 (unknown superposition of \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9) is transduced into a photonic qubit (time\u2010bin or dual\u2010rail) via a quantum transducer.  \n2. Node B also has a transducer coupled to a superconducting qubit initially prepared in one arm of an optical Bell pair; the other photon of that pair will later be used in the Bell measurement.  \n3. The flying photonic qubit from A and one photon of the Bell pair from B are routed to a central linear\u2010optics station, where a Bell\u2010state analyzer (beam splitters + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors) performs a joint measurement. Two ancillary detectors register a successful Bell outcome.  \n4. Upon heralding, classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus\u2019s scope) directs a Pauli correction on superconducting qubit B, completing teleportation.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources: [S_trans_A] [S_Bell1] [S_Bell2]  \noptical network: [beam splitters, phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla1][ancilla2] [out_\u03c8]  \n\nHere [out_\u03c8] feeds the teleported qubit back into superconducting qubit B (via its transducer in reverse).  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 Extend to repeater chains by adding intermediate transducers and swapping stations between nodes.  \n\u2022 Replace the two-photon Bell pair source at B with a scalable multi-photon resource for cluster-state\u2013based teleportation.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation between superconducting qubits via quantum transduction and linear\u2010optics Bell measurement',  \n 'foldername': 'TransducerTeleport',  \n 'num_anc': 2,  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1],        # 0=transduced \u03c8 from A, 1=one photon of Bell pair from B  \n 'out_nodes': [2],         # teleported \u03c8 arrives here  \n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],  # perfect correlation between input bit and output bit  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,2]], # no direct source\u2010to\u2010output link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'number_resolving': True,  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1], # treat both transduced qubit and Bell\u2010pair photon as single\u2010photon sources  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops in Pytheus; only linear optics, probabilistic sources, and photon detection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The idea must go beyond straightforward teleportation; you need to introduce a genuinely new network primitive or measurement that isn\u2019t already just the standard Bell\u2010swap/teleport protocol. (Too close to textbook teleportation.)\n    b) A repeater segment: two entanglement\u2010swapping stations between three superconducting nodes. (Structurally like existing multi\u2010swap examples.)\n    c) A \u201cteleportation router\u201d that uses a single joint linear\u2010optics measurement to teleport an unknown qubit from A onto either B or C, purely by heralding patterns\u2014no active switching, just post\u2010selection.  \n  Step 2: Novelty/obstacles:\n    a) Already textbook; little new network primitive.  \n    b) Already covered by multi\u2010swap examples.  \n    c) Novel: conditional routing of a qubit to different receivers via measurement\u2010induced network branching. Pytheus can optimize a fixed multiport interferometer plus detectors; no feedback required.  \n  Step 3: Pick (c), the teleportation router.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it realizes a new quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014measurement\u2010induced routing of a quantum state to one of multiple solid\u2010state nodes\u2014using transduction plus linear optics, without dynamic switches.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since it only uses single\u2010photon sources (the two transducers and two Bell\u2010pair sources), a static multiport interferometer, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors; no cavities or feedback.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nExplanation:\nWe propose a \u201cquantum teleportation router\u201d linking three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes (A, B, C) via quantum transduction and a single linear\u2010optics measurement. An unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 on A is mapped to a photonic qubit via its transducer (source S_A). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources at B and C emit optical Bell pairs (S_B and S_C). Half of each Bell pair remains at the respective node as the target memory; the other halves are sent to a central multiport interferometer. In that interferometer the photon from A and the two \u201cflying\u201d Bell photons are mixed in a fixed three\u2010input linear\u2010optics network. Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record one of two distinct heralding patterns\u2014pattern P_B heralds teleportation of \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 onto B\u2019s retained photon, pattern P_C heralds teleportation onto C\u2019s retained photon. No active switching is required; the routing choice is made by post\u2010selection.  \n\nVisualization (sources send photons downwards):\nsources:   [S_A]   [S_B]   [S_C]  \nnetwork:   [three\u2010input beam splitters + phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla detectors P1,P2,P3]  \nmemories:  [qubit B]  [qubit C]  \n\nWhen the detectors click in pattern P_B (e.g. clicks on D1+D2), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at B\u2019s memory; if they click in P_C (D2+D3), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at C\u2019s memory.  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N receivers by adding N Bell sources and routing via an N+1\u2010port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use delayed\u2010choice routing by deferring which heralding pattern is selected for key\u2010agreement or multi\u2010party protocols.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation router: A\u2192{B or C} via transducers & static linear optics',  \n 'foldername': 'TeleportationRouter',  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1,2],      # 0=S_A, 1=S_B(idler), 2=S_C(idler)  \n 'num_anc': 3,                    # three ancilla detectors in the multiport  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1,2],             # 0=A\u2019s photon; 1,2=Bell photons sent for measurement  \n 'out_nodes': [3,4],              # 3=B\u2019s retained photon; 4=C\u2019s retained photon  \n 'target_quantum': ['000','100','011','111'],  \n   # Interpret '000' & '100' as patterns P_B routing 0\u2192B, '011'/'111' as P_C routing to C  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,3],[0,4]],  \n   # no direct source\u2010to\u2010memory link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops\u2014only static linear optics, probabilistic sources, and post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel, you must go beyond straightforward teleportation routing. Propose a genuinely new multi-node primitive (e.g. non-trivial interference of multiple swap orders, programmable higher-dimensional routing, indefinite causal structures, etc.) or leverage unique transducer physics as an integral network element rather than just a state interface.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:  \nWe need a genuinely new network primitive that goes beyond textbook teleportation or simple swapping\u2014one that combines superconducting circuits, quantum transduction, and only linear optics plus single\u2010photon sources, with no cavities or active feedback. A promising idea is to perform simultaneous, bidirectional teleportation between two superconducting nodes in one joint interferometric measurement. This \u201ctwo\u2010way teleportation\u201d network teleports \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081\u2192\u2082 and \u2223\u03d5\u27e9\u2082\u2192\u2081 at the same time via four flying photons and a single static linear\u2010optics station. It introduces a novel network transformation (bidirectional channel) rather than just state generation and can be generalized to multi\u2010party two\u2010way links or repeater segments.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a \u201cbidirectional teleportation channel\u201d between two superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A and B implemented with quantum transducers and a single four\u2010input linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010measurement station. In one heralded run, A\u2019s unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 and B\u2019s unknown qubit \u2223\u03d5\u27e9\u2082 are simultaneously teleported to B and A, respectively.  \n\n1. Node A: superconducting qubit in state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 transduced into a photonic qubit via source S_A.  \n2. Node B: superconducting qubit in state \u2223\u03d5\u27e9 transduced into a photonic qubit via source S_B.  \n3. Both nodes also host an on\u2010site Bell\u2010pair source: S_BellA at A and S_BellB at B. Each emits an optical Bell pair; one photon of each pair stays as the memory qubit (to receive the teleported state), the other travels to the central station.  \n4. Four flying photons (from S_A, S_B, S_BellA-idler, S_BellB-idler) enter a static four\u2010port interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters). Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record the joint outcome.  \n5. Two distinct heralding patterns both signal successful bidirectional teleportation:  \n   \u2022 Pattern P\u2081 = clicks at detectors D0 & D1  (no clicks at D2,D3)  \n   \u2022 Pattern P\u2082 = clicks at detectors D2 & D3  (no clicks at D0,D1)  \n   In either case, the memories at A (from S_BellA-signal) and B (from S_BellB-signal) now hold \u2223\u03d5\u27e9 and \u2223\u03c8\u27e9, respectively. No active switching is required\u2014routing emerges by conditional post\u2010selection on P\u2081 or P\u2082.  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 Extend to multi\u2010party bidirectional links by adding more transducers and a higher\u2010input interferometer.  \n\u2022 Build two\u2010way repeater chains by concatenating such joint measurements across segments.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:  \n{'description': 'Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation between superconducting qubits via quantum transduction and a single linear\u2010optics station',  \n 'foldername': 'BiTeleport',  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1,2,3],   # 0=S_A (\u03c8), 1=S_B (\u03d5), 2=S_BellA-idler, 3=S_BellB-idler  \n 'num_anc': 4,                    # four detectors in the Bell station  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1,2,3],           # inputs to the interferometer  \n 'out_nodes': [],                 # no direct memory detectors  \n 'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3],      # detectors 0\u20133 register herald patterns  \n 'target_quantum': ['1100','0011'], # D0&D1 or D2&D3 click patterns  \n 'removed_connections': [],       # all sources can connect to any detector  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops\u2014only static linear optics, single-photon emitters (for transduced qubits and Bell pairs), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. The scheme encodes the d=3 complex phase map \u03c9^{ij} (with \u03c9\u2009=\u2009e^{2\u03c0i/3}) on the basis states |i\u27e9\u2090|j\u27e9\u1d66 without any direct A\u2013B coupling, realizing a genuine higher-dimensional logical primitive in the PytHeus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n\u201cSingle-Shot Nonlocal String-Order Correlator Network via Linear-Optical Entanglement Swapping\u201d\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe implement the Nonlocal String-Order Correlator Network, a purely linear-optical, non-factorizable tensor-network contraction that directly measures the MPS string-order operator \u27e8\u03c8|Z\u2081X\u2082\u2026X\u2099\u208b\u2081Z\u2099|\u03c8\u27e9 in one heralded entanglement-swapping step. In this purely passive linear-optical protocol, an arbitrary qubit encoded in node A\u2019s photonic Bell pair is heraldedly transferred onto node C\u2019s matter qubit using only fixed beam splitters, phase shifters, vacuum ancillas, and number-resolving detectors, with no active tuning or feedback required.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network.
