Teleportation is just entanglement swapping plus local corrections, so this offers no genuinely new measurement topology or network function.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme must introduce a fundamentally new LOQC primitive beyond the quantum-SWITCH of Bell measurements\u2014e.g. a nontrivial multi-order superposition of different network tasks, a higher-dimensional or non-Hermitian twist, or an active use of the transducer physics within the optical network itself\u2014rather than simply superposing two teleportation sequences.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Explanation:\nWe propose to implement a post\u2010selected Fredkin gate (controlled\u2010SWAP) among three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A (control), B (target1), and C (target2) using quantum transduction and a single static linear\u2010optics station. In one heralded run, the unknown states \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A, \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B, and \u2223\u03c7\u27e9_C are simultaneously transduced into three photonic qubits via transducers (single_emitters). An ancillary photon\u2010pair source provides two extra photons for the linear\u2010optics network. All five photons enter a fixed interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters) and are measured by four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. A specific two\u2010click heralding pattern signals successful implementation of the Fredkin truth table: if A\u2019s control bit is 0, B and C remain unchanged; if it is 1, their states are swapped. Upon heralding, the photonic outputs are mapped back to the superconducting memories at A, B, and C.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Post\u2010selected Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) between three superconducting qubits via transduction & LOQC',\n  'foldername': 'Fredkin_FF',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # 0=S_A (control), 1=S_B (target1), 2=S_C (target2)\n  'pair_sources': [3],              # 3=ancilla Bell\u2010pair source\n  'num_anc': 4,                     # four detectors for heralding\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,4,5],          # flying: control, t1, t2, ancilla idlers\n  'heralding_out': [6,7,8,9],       # detectors D6\u2026D9\n  'out_nodes': [0,1,2],             # photonic outputs remapped to qubit memories\n  'target_quantum': [\n    '000','001','010','011',        # c=0 \u21d2 identity on t1,t2\n    '100','110','101','111'         # c=1 \u21d2 swap t1<->t2\n  ],\n  'removed_connections': [],        # all sources can connect to all detectors\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n\u2013 No prior Pytheus experiment has implemented a Fredkin gate across remote superconducting nodes.  \n\u2013 It leverages quantum transduction as the only interface to a purely linear\u2010optics network, realizing a nontrivial three\u2010party gate (controlled\u2010SWAP) rather than mere state generation or pairwise swapping.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible:\n\u2013 Pytheus can optimize static interferometers with single\u2010photon and pair sources plus detectors.  \n\u2013 No cavities or dynamic feedback controls are needed\u2014just post\u2010selection on heralding patterns to enact the Fredkin truth table.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially the same controlled\u2010SWAP (Fredkin) primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cHeralded Measurement\u2010Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization\u2010Encoded Target Qubits\u201d), merely wrapped with superconducting\u2010to\u2010photon transducers. It offers no new interferometer topology, measurement primitive, or nontrivial network function beyond that existing heralded Fredkin gate.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme must introduce a genuinely new LOQC primitive or multi\u2010node function\u2014such as nontrivial superpositions of swap orders, higher\u2010dimensional routing, an indefinite causal structure, or an active role for transducer physics inside the linear\u2010optical network\u2014rather than repackaging the standard Fredkin gate with transduction.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Explanation:\nWe propose to implement an indefinite\u2010order teleportation channel (a quantum SWITCH) between two distant superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A and B, mediated by quantum transduction and a single static linear\u2010optics station. A flying control photonic qubit coherently superposes the order in which the teleportation A\u2192B and B\u2192A occur\u2014no dynamic elements, only post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Node A: unknown qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A is transduced into a photonic qubit by single\u2010photon source S_A.  \n2. Node B: unknown qubit state \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B is transduced by single\u2010photon source S_B.  \n3. Each node hosts a Bell\u2010pair source P_A at A and P_B at B. One photon of each pair remains stored locally as the memory; the other (idler) travels to the central station.  \n4. A control single\u2010photon source S_C prepares |+\u27e9=(|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. Depending on its spatial mode, the interferometer enacts either the A-then-B teleportation sequence or the B-then-A sequence.  \n5. The five flying photons (control, S_A, S_B, P_A-idler, P_B-idler) enter a fixed five-port beam-splitter network. Five photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record the herald.  \n6. Two distinct two-click patterns\u2014e.g. D0&D1 (\u201cA then B\u201d) or D2&D3 (\u201cB then A\u201d)\u2014herald successful teleportation in the respective order. Because the control qubit was |+\u27e9, the overall process coherently superposes both orders, realizing an indefinite causal order of two teleportation channels. After heralding, classical feed-forward applies Pauli corrections on A\u2019s and B\u2019s stored photons, completing both teleports.\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-channel quantum SWITCHes by adding more Bell sources and enlarging the static interferometer.  \n\u2022 Explore superpositions of arbitrary network\u2010operation orders or embed the control qubit within higher-dimensional encodings.\n\nPytheus-style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum-SWITCH of two teleportation channels between superconducting nodes A\u2194B via flying control qubit',\n  'foldername': 'TeleportSwitch_QSWITCH',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],        # 0=S_C (control), 1=S_A (\u03c8), 2=S_B (\u03c6)\n  'pair_sources':    [3,4],          # 3=P_A, 4=P_B\n  'num_anc':         5,              # five detectors D0\u2026D4\n  'in_nodes':        [0,1,2,5,6],     # flying: control(0), \u03c8(1), \u03c6(2), P_A\u2010idler(5), P_B\u2010idler(6)\n  'heralding_out':   [0,1,2,3,4],     # detectors register herald patterns\n  'out_nodes':       [],             # memories at A/B are offline\n  'target_quantum':  ['11000','00110'], \n     # '11000' = D0&D1 click \u21d2 \u201cA\u2192B then B\u2192A\u201d;  \n     # '00110' = D2&D3 click \u21d2 \u201cB\u2192A then A\u2192B\u201d\n  'removed_connections': [],         # full connectivity\n  'thresholds':       [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer':        'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':        'cr',\n  'samples':          20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNo cavities or feedback loops\u2014only single\u2010photon transducers, probabilistic pair sources, a static linear\u2010optics network, and post-selected heralding. This unlocks a new hybrid quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014indefinite causal order of teleportation\u2014for superconducting circuits.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While interlinking teleportation channels in an indefinite causal order is conceptually appealing, this proposal reduces to the same quantum\u2010SWITCH of two Bell-swap (teleportation) operations already covered by existing ensemble suggestions (e.g. \u201cImplementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\u201d). Teleportation is simply entanglement swapping plus local corrections, so there is no new linear-optical network topology or measurement primitive here.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel, your experiment must introduce a fundamentally new LOQC primitive or exploit the transducer physics as an active network element\u2014such as superposing different non-swap operations, higher-dimensional causal structures, or non-Hermitian measurement effects\u2014rather than reusing the standard quantum-SWITCH of Bell measurements."

Half of each Bell pair remains at the respective node as the target memory; the other halves are sent to a central multiport interferometer. In that interferometer the photon from A and the two \u201cflying\u201d Bell photons are mixed in a fixed three\u2010input linear\u2010optics network. No active switching is required; the routing choice is made by post\u2010selection.  \n\nVisualization (sources send photons downwards):\nsources:   [S_A]   [S_B]   [S_C]  \nnetwork:   [three\u2010input beam splitters + phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla detectors P1,P2,P3]  \nmemories:  [qubit B]  [qubit C]  \n\nWhen the detectors click in pattern P_B (e.g. clicks on D1+D2), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at B\u2019s memory; if they click in P_C (D2+D3), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at C\u2019s memory.  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N receivers by adding N Bell sources and routing via an N+1\u2010port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use delayed\u2010choice routing by deferring which heralding pattern is selected for key\u2010agreement or multi\u2010party protocols.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation router: A\u2192{B or C} via transducers & static linear optics',  \n 'foldername': 'TeleportationRouter',  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1,2],      # 0=S_A, 1=S_B(idler), 2=S_C(idler)  \n 'num_anc': 3,                    # three ancilla detectors in the multiport  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1,2],             # 0=A\u2019s photon; 1,2=Bell photons sent for measurement  \n 'out_nodes': [3,4],              # 3=B\u2019s retained photon; 4=C\u2019s retained photon  \n 'target_quantum': ['000','100','011','111'],  \n   # Interpret '000' & '100' as patterns P_B routing 0\u2192B, '011'/'111' as P_C routing to C  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,3],[0,4]],  \n   # no direct source\u2010to\u2010memory link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops\u2014only static linear optics, probabilistic sources, and post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel, you must go beyond straightforward teleportation routing. Input:  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a \u201ccyclic teleportation channel\u201d (a 3-cycle SWAP gate) between three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A, B, and C, mediated by quantum transduction and a single static linear\u2010optics station. In one heralded run, A\u2019s state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 is teleported to B, B\u2019s state \u2223\u03d5\u27e9\u2082 to C, and C\u2019s state \u2223\u03c7\u27e9\u2083 back to A, all simultaneously and without dynamic routing.  \n\nProtocol outline:  \n1. At each node X\u2208{A,B,C}, the superconducting qubit in unknown state \u2223\u03be\u27e9\u2093 is mapped to a photonic qubit via a quantum transducer (single\u2010photon source S\u2093).  \n2. Each node also hosts a local Bell\u2010pair source (probabilistic photon\u2010pair source P\u2093): one photon remains stored as the target memory at X; its partner (the idler) is sent to the central station.  \n3. The six flying photons (three from transducers S_A,S_B,S_C; three idlers from P_A,P_B,P_C) enter a fixed six\u2010input linear\u2010optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters) and are measured by six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n4. A single successful click pattern\u2014for instance \u201cD0&D1, D2&D3, D4&D5\u201d (two clicks per teleportation)\u2014heralds that the three Bell measurements have all succeeded, resulting in the cyclic permutation: the memories at A,B,C now contain \u2223\u03c7\u27e9\u2083,\u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081,\u2223\u03d5\u27e9\u2082 respectively.  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 N-cycle permutation channels among N superconducting nodes via an (2N)-port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Concatenate cyclic channels to form programmable network\u2010topology modules.  \n\u2022 Explore indefinite\u2010order permutations by coherent control over heralding subsets.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:  \n{  \n  'description': 'Cyclic teleportation (3-cycle SWAP) between three superconducting nodes via transduction and linear optics',  \n  'foldername': '3CycleTeleport',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 40,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_anc': 6,                     # six detectors at the Bell\u2010station  \n  'num_pre': 1,  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # S_A, S_B, S_C: transduced qubits  \n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,3,4,5],        # the six flying photons  \n  'out_nodes': [],                  # all photons are measured; memories are offline  \n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # detectors D0\u2026D5 record clicks  \n  'target_quantum': ['110011','001100'],  \n      # e.g. clicks at {D0,D1,D4,D5} or {D2,D3,D4,D5} herald the cyclic SWAP  \n  'removed_connections': [],        # fully connected interferometer  \n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n  'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no dynamic feedback\u2014only deterministic single\u2010photon emitters (for transducers), probabilistic pair sources (for Bell resources), a static linear\u2010optics network, and post-selected heralding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates the \u201cMeasurement\u2010Induced Photonic Realization of the Three\u2010Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring\u2010Exchange\u201d already in our ensemble. Two sender nodes, A and C, each hold an unknown superconducting\u2010qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A and \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C to be simultaneously teleported across the network to receivers D and B, respectively, even though the network\u2019s optical\u2010fiber layout is the minimal \u201cbutterfly\u201d shape.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Nodes A and C each transduce their unknown qubit (\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A, \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C) into a photonic qubit via a single\u2010photon source (S_A, S_C).  \n2. At A and C, independent Bell\u2010pair sources (P_A, P_C) generate a second photon each; those idler photons are also sent to the central station, while their partner photons remain stored locally as the target memories at D and B, respectively.  \n3. A total of four flying photons (two from the unknown\u2010state transducers, two idlers from Bell sources) enter a central static 4\u2010input linear\u2010optics network that realizes two overlapping Bell\u2010measurements in the butterfly configuration: the \u201cXOR\u2010node\u201d of the butterfly combines one output of A\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement with one output of C\u2019s, implementing the network coding.  \n4. Six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (two per Bell\u2010measurement) record four\u2010click heralding patterns that correspond to successful network\u2010coded teleportation. Conditioned on the specific click pattern, \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A appears in node D\u2019s memory and \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C appears in node B\u2019s memory.  \n5. Classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus) applies Pauli corrections on the stored photons at B and D, completing the teleportation.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources: [S_A] [P_A\u2010idler] [P_C\u2010idler] [S_C]  \nnetwork: [4-input \u201cbutterfly\u201d interferometer implementing two Bell+XOR nodes]  \ndetectors: [D0][D1][D2][D3][D4][D5]  \nmemories: [qubit D]    [qubit B]  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to larger network\u2010coding graphs (e.g. two\u2010source multi\u2010receiver multicast channels).  \n\u2022 Replace the static XOR node by programmable interferometers to realize different network functions.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum butterfly network\u2010coding teleportation between nodes A,C \u2192 D,B via transducers & static linear optics',\n  'foldername': 'ButterflyTeleport',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2,3],       # 0=S_A(\u03c8), 1=P_A\u2010idler, 2=P_C\u2010idler, 3=S_C(\u03c6)\n  'num_anc': 6,                       # six detectors\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,3],              # flying photons into network\n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # detectors D0\u2013D5\n  'out_nodes': [],                    # memories are offline at D and B\n  'target_quantum': ['110000','001100'],  \n    # e.g. patterns corresponding to XOR of two Bell\u2010measure outcomes\n  'removed_connections': [],          # full connectivity for optimization\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNo cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, single-photon transducers, and post\u2010selected heralding.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s butterfly network-coded joint measurement. Pytheus already handled CNOTs and Toffolis but not the Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) gate. A heralded Fredkin between three remote superconducting qubits\u2014each mapped via a transducer into flying single photons\u2014realizes a nontrivial three\u2010party gate across the network. It requires only single\u2010photon sources, one ancillary photon pair, a static interferometer, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nExplanation:\nWe propose to implement a post\u2010selected Fredkin gate (controlled\u2010SWAP) among three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A (control), B (target1), and C (target2) using quantum transduction and a single static linear\u2010optics station. In one heralded run, the unknown states \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A, \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B, and \u2223\u03c7\u27e9_C are simultaneously transduced into three photonic qubits via transducers (single_emitters). An ancillary photon\u2010pair source provides two extra photons for the linear\u2010optics network. All five photons enter a fixed interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters) and are measured by four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. A specific two\u2010click heralding pattern signals successful implementation of the Fredkin truth table: if A\u2019s control bit is 0, B and C remain unchanged; if it is 1, their states are swapped. Upon heralding, the photonic outputs are mapped back to the superconducting memories at A, B, and C.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Post\u2010selected Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) between three superconducting qubits via transduction & LOQC',\n  'foldername': 'Fredkin_FF',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # 0=S_A (control), 1=S_B (target1), 2=S_C (target2)\n  'pair_sources': [3],              # 3=ancilla Bell\u2010pair source\n  'num_anc': 4,                     # four detectors for heralding\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,4,5],          # flying: control, t1, t2, ancilla idlers\n  'heralding_out': [6,7,8,9],       # detectors D6\u2026D9\n  'out_nodes': [0,1,2],             # photonic outputs remapped to qubit memories\n  'target_quantum': [\n    '000','001','010','011',        # c=0 \u21d2 identity on t1,t2\n    '100','110','101','111'         # c=1 \u21d2 swap t1<->t2\n  ],\n  'removed_connections': [],        # all sources can connect to all detectors\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n\u2013 No prior Pytheus experiment has implemented a Fredkin gate across remote superconducting nodes.  \n\u2013 It leverages quantum transduction as the only interface to a purely linear\u2010optics network, realizing a nontrivial three\u2010party gate (controlled\u2010SWAP) rather than mere state generation or pairwise swapping.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible:\n\u2013 Pytheus can optimize static interferometers with single\u2010photon and pair sources plus detectors.  \n\u2013 No cavities or dynamic feedback controls are needed\u2014just post\u2010selection on heralding patterns to enact the Fredkin truth table.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme must introduce a genuinely new LOQC primitive or multi\u2010node function\u2014such as nontrivial superpositions of swap orders, higher\u2010dimensional routing, an indefinite causal structure, or an active role for transducer physics inside the linear\u2010optical network\u2014rather than repackaging the standard Fredkin gate with transduction.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new LOQC network primitive\u2014no mere state generation\u2014combining superconducting\u2010qubit transduction and linear optics. Of our brainstorms, the most novel is to place two teleportation channels (A\u2192B and B\u2192A) in an indefinite causal order via a flying control photon. Pytheus can optimize a static interferometer mixing the control qubit with the four Bell\u2010measurement photons, with no active switching or feedback. This realizes a \u201cquantum SWITCH\u201d of teleportation channels between two remote superconducting nodes.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExplanation:\nWe propose to implement an indefinite\u2010order teleportation channel (a quantum SWITCH) between two distant superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A and B, mediated by quantum transduction and a single static linear\u2010optics station. A flying control photonic qubit coherently superposes the order in which the teleportation A\u2192B and B\u2192A occur\u2014no dynamic elements, only post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Node A: unknown qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A is transduced into a photonic qubit by single\u2010photon source S_A.  \n2. Node B: unknown qubit state \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B is transduced by single\u2010photon source S_B.  \n3. Each node hosts a Bell\u2010pair source P_A at A and P_B at B. One photon of each pair remains stored locally as the memory; the other (idler) travels to the central station.  \n4. A control single\u2010photon source S_C prepares |+\u27e9=(|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. Depending on its spatial mode, the interferometer enacts either the A-then-B teleportation sequence or the B-then-A sequence.  \n5. The five flying photons (control, S_A, S_B, P_A-idler, P_B-idler) enter a fixed five-port beam-splitter network. Five photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record the herald.  \n6. Two distinct two-click patterns\u2014e.g. D0&D1 (\u201cA then B\u201d) or D2&D3 (\u201cB then A\u201d)\u2014herald successful teleportation in the respective order. Because the control qubit was |+\u27e9, the overall process coherently superposes both orders, realizing an indefinite causal order of two teleportation channels. After heralding, classical feed-forward applies Pauli corrections on A\u2019s and B\u2019s stored photons, completing both teleports.\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-channel quantum SWITCHes by adding more Bell sources and enlarging the static interferometer.  \n\u2022 Explore superpositions of arbitrary network\u2010operation orders or embed the control qubit within higher-dimensional encodings.\n\nPytheus-style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum-SWITCH of two teleportation channels between superconducting nodes A\u2194B via flying control qubit',\n  'foldername': 'TeleportSwitch_QSWITCH',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],        # 0=S_C (control), 1=S_A (\u03c8), 2=S_B (\u03c6)\n  'pair_sources':    [3,4],          # 3=P_A, 4=P_B\n  'num_anc':         5,              # five detectors D0\u2026D4\n  'in_nodes':        [0,1,2,5,6],     # flying: control(0), \u03c8(1), \u03c6(2), P_A\u2010idler(5), P_B\u2010idler(6)\n  'heralding_out':   [0,1,2,3,4],     # detectors register herald patterns\n  'out_nodes':       [],             # memories at A/B are offline\n  'target_quantum':  ['11000','00110'], \n     # '11000' = D0&D1 click \u21d2 \u201cA\u2192B then B\u2192A\u201d;  \n     # '00110' = D2&D3 click \u21d2 \u201cB\u2192A then A\u2192B\u201d\n  'removed_connections': [],         # full connectivity\n  'thresholds':       [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer':        'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':        'cr',\n  'samples':          20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNo cavities or feedback loops\u2014only single\u2010photon transducers, probabilistic pair sources, a static linear\u2010optics network, and post-selected heralding. This unlocks a new hybrid quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014indefinite causal order of teleportation\u2014for superconducting circuits.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel, your experiment must introduce a fundamentally new LOQC primitive or exploit the transducer physics as an active network element\u2014such as superposing different non-swap operations, higher-dimensional causal structures, or non-Hermitian measurement effects\u2014rather than reusing the standard quantum-SWITCH of Bell measurements.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Explanation:\nWe propose a heralded remote CNOT gate between two superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A (control) and B (target), mediated by quantum transducers and a single static linear\u2010optics station. Instead of merely swapping or teleporting states, this network implements the nontrivial two\u2010qubit transformation CNOT directly on the distant memories.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. At node A, the superconducting control\u2010qubit state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 is converted into a single photonic qubit via a quantum transducer (single\u2010photon emitter S_A).  \n2. At node B, the superconducting target\u2010qubit state |\u03d5\u27e9\u2082 is likewise transduced into a photonic qubit (single\u2010photon emitter S_B).  \n3. A central ancilla Bell\u2010pair source P generates two entangled photons; both idlers are sent to the LOQC station, while the partner photons remain stored locally at A and B as the output memories.  \n4. The four flying photons (S_A, S_B, P_idler1, P_idler2) are injected into a fixed linear\u2010optics network of beam splitters and phase shifters. Two photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record a specific two\u2010click heralding pattern that signals successful implementation of the CNOT truth table.  \n5. Upon heralding, the two stored photons at A and B now carry the output qubits: the control bit unchanged and the target bit flipped if\u2014and only if\u2014the control was |1\u27e9. Classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus) applies any required Pauli corrections to complete the gate.\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n\u2013 Previous Pytheus experiments realized local CNOTs or teleportation channels; no experiment has yet demonstrated a heralded two\u2010qubit gate acting directly on two remote superconducting memories via photonic transduction.  \n\u2013 This transforms the network into an active quantum processor primitive, not merely a state generator or swap.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in Pytheus:\n\u2013 Only single\u2010photon emitters (two transducers + two ancilla idlers), a static interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors are required\u2014no cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\u2013 Pytheus can optimize the beam-splitter network and detector assignments to realize the desired two-click heralding pattern for the CNOT truth table.  \n\nPytheus-style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description':          'Heralded remote CNOT between superconducting qubits via quantum transduction & linear optics',\n  'foldername':           'RemoteCNOT',\n  'single_emitters':      [0,1],         # 0 = S_A (control), 1 = S_B (target)\n  'pair_sources':         [2],           # 2 = ancilla Bell\u2010pair source\n  'num_anc':              2,             # two detectors for heralding\n  'in_nodes':             [0,1],         # control_in, target_in\n  'out_nodes':            [3,4],         # control_out (memory A), target_out (memory B)\n  'heralding_out':        [5,6],         # detector nodes D5,D6\n  'target_quantum':       ['0000','0101','1011','1110'],  \n                          # input-output mapping: 00\u219200, 01\u219201, 10\u219211, 11\u219210 (control,target order)\n  'removed_connections':  [[0,3],[1,4]], # forbid direct transducer\u2192memory paths\n  'thresholds':           [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer':            'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':            'cr',\n  'samples':              20,\n  'number_resolving':     True\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n\u2022 Concatenate such remote CNOTs to form distributed photonic\u2010mediated gate networks among many superconducting nodes.  \n\u2022 Replace the single ancilla pair with a small photonic cluster resource to realize higher\u2010order gates (e.g. Toffoli) in the same transduction + LOQC framework."
}

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. An unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 on A is mapped to a photonic qubit via its transducer (source S_A). Two independent Bell\u2010pair sources at B and C emit optical Bell pairs (S_B and S_C). Half of each Bell pair remains at the respective node as the target memory; the other halves are sent to a central multiport interferometer. In that interferometer the photon from A and the two \u201cflying\u201d Bell photons are mixed in a fixed three\u2010input linear\u2010optics network. Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record one of two distinct heralding patterns\u2014pattern P_B heralds teleportation of \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 onto B\u2019s retained photon, pattern P_C heralds teleportation onto C\u2019s retained photon. No active switching is required; the routing choice is made by post\u2010selection.  \n\nVisualization (sources send photons downwards):\nsources:   [S_A]   [S_B]   [S_C]  \nnetwork:   [three\u2010input beam splitters + phase shifters]  \ndetectors: [ancilla detectors P1,P2,P3]  \nmemories:  [qubit B]  [qubit C]  \n\nWhen the detectors click in pattern P_B (e.g. clicks on D1+D2), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at B\u2019s memory; if they click in P_C (D2+D3), \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 appears at C\u2019s memory.  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N receivers by adding N Bell sources and routing via an N+1\u2010port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use delayed\u2010choice routing by deferring which heralding pattern is selected for key\u2010agreement or multi\u2010party protocols.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{'description': 'Teleportation router: A\u2192{B or C} via transducers & static linear optics',  \n 'foldername': 'TeleportationRouter',  \n 'single_emitters': [0,1,2],      # 0=S_A, 1=S_B(idler), 2=S_C(idler)  \n 'num_anc': 3,                    # three ancilla detectors in the multiport  \n 'in_nodes': [0,1,2],             # 0=A\u2019s photon; 1,2=Bell photons sent for measurement  \n 'out_nodes': [3,4],              # 3=B\u2019s retained photon; 4=C\u2019s retained photon  \n 'target_quantum': ['000','100','011','111'],  \n   # Interpret '000' & '100' as patterns P_B routing 0\u2192B, '011'/'111' as P_C routing to C  \n 'removed_connections': [[0,3],[0,4]],  \n   # no direct source\u2010to\u2010memory link  \n 'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'samples': 20,  \n 'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops\u2014only static linear optics, probabilistic sources, and post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel, you must go beyond straightforward teleportation routing. Bell\u2010measurement station.  \n  b) A linear\u2010optics \u201crouter\u201d that teleports a qubit from A to either B or C based on which detector pattern fires.  \n  c) A cyclic\u2010swap channel that simultaneously permutes qubit states \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081\u2192\u2082, \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2082\u2192\u2083, \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2083\u2192\u2081 between three superconducting nodes in one joint interferometric measurement.  \nStep 2:  \n  a) Too textbook.  \n  b) Interesting but close to previous \u201crouter\u201d proposals.  \n  c) Novel network primitive (3-cycle SWAP) not yet explored in Pytheus, and easily generalized to N-cycle permutation channels.  \nStep 3: Pick (c).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements the primitive of a cyclic permutation (3-SWAP gate) across three distant superconducting qubits in one static photonic network, rather than just pairwise teleportation or entanglement swapping.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since it only Input:  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a \u201ccyclic teleportation channel\u201d (a 3-cycle SWAP gate) between three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A, B, and C, mediated by quantum transduction and a single static linear\u2010optics station. In one heralded run, A\u2019s state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 is teleported to B, B\u2019s state \u2223\u03d5\u27e9\u2082 to C, and C\u2019s state \u2223\u03c7\u27e9\u2083 back to A, all simultaneously and without dynamic routing.  \n\nProtocol outline:  \n1. At each node X\u2208{A,B,C}, the superconducting qubit in unknown state \u2223\u03be\u27e9\u2093 is mapped to a photonic qubit via a quantum transducer (single\u2010photon source S\u2093).  \n2. Each node also hosts a local Bell\u2010pair source (probabilistic photon\u2010pair source P\u2093): one photon remains stored as the target memory at X; its partner (the idler) is sent to the central station.  \n3. The six flying photons (three from transducers S_A,S_B,S_C; three idlers from P_A,P_B,P_C) enter a fixed six\u2010input linear\u2010optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters) and are measured by six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n4. A single successful click pattern\u2014for instance \u201cD0&D1, D2&D3, D4&D5\u201d (two clicks per teleportation)\u2014heralds that the three Bell measurements have all succeeded, resulting in the cyclic permutation: the memories at A,B,C now contain \u2223\u03c7\u27e9\u2083,\u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081,\u2223\u03d5\u27e9\u2082 respectively.  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 N-cycle permutation channels among N superconducting nodes via an (2N)-port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Concatenate cyclic channels to form programmable network\u2010topology modules.  \n\u2022 Explore indefinite\u2010order permutations by coherent control over heralding subsets.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:  \n{  \n  'description': 'Cyclic teleportation (3-cycle SWAP) between three superconducting nodes via transduction and linear optics',  \n  'foldername': '3CycleTeleport',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 40,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_anc': 6,                     # six detectors at the Bell\u2010station  \n  'num_pre': 1,  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # S_A, S_B, S_C: transduced qubits  \n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,3,4,5],        # the six flying photons  \n  'out_nodes': [],                  # all photons are measured; memories are offline  \n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # detectors D0\u2026D5 record clicks  \n  'target_quantum': ['110011','001100'],  \n      # e.g. clicks at {D0,D1,D4,D5} or {D2,D3,D4,D5} herald the cyclic SWAP  \n  'removed_connections': [],        # fully connected interferometer  \n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n  'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nNo cavities, no dynamic feedback\u2014only deterministic single\u2010photon emitters (for transducers), probabilistic pair sources (for Bell resources), a static linear\u2010optics network, and post-selected heralding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates the \u201cMeasurement\u2010Induced Photonic Realization of the Three\u2010Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring\u2010Exchange\u201d already in our ensemble. Two sender nodes, A and C, each hold an unknown superconducting\u2010qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A and \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C to be simultaneously teleported across the network to receivers D and B, respectively, even though the network\u2019s optical\u2010fiber layout is the minimal \u201cbutterfly\u201d shape.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Nodes A and C each transduce their unknown qubit (\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A, \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C) into a photonic qubit via a single\u2010photon source (S_A, S_C).  \n2. At A and C, independent Bell\u2010pair sources (P_A, P_C) generate a second photon each; those idler photons are also sent to the central station, while their partner photons remain stored locally as the target memories at D and B, respectively.  \n3. A total of four flying photons (two from the unknown\u2010state transducers, two idlers from Bell sources) enter a central static 4\u2010input linear\u2010optics network that realizes two overlapping Bell\u2010measurements in the butterfly configuration: the \u201cXOR\u2010node\u201d of the butterfly combines one output of A\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement with one output of C\u2019s, implementing the network coding.  \n4. Six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (two per Bell\u2010measurement) record four\u2010click heralding patterns that correspond to successful network\u2010coded teleportation. Conditioned on the specific click pattern, \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A appears in node D\u2019s memory and \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C appears in node B\u2019s memory.  \n5. Classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus) applies Pauli corrections on the stored photons at B and D, completing the teleportation.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources: [S_A] [P_A\u2010idler] [P_C\u2010idler] [S_C]  \nnetwork: [4-input \u201cbutterfly\u201d interferometer implementing two Bell+XOR nodes]  \ndetectors: [D0][D1][D2][D3][D4][D5]  \nmemories: [qubit D]    [qubit B]  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to larger network\u2010coding graphs (e.g. two\u2010source multi\u2010receiver multicast channels).  \n\u2022 Replace the static XOR node by programmable interferometers to realize different network functions.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum butterfly network\u2010coding teleportation between nodes A,C \u2192 D,B via transducers & static linear optics',\n  'foldername': 'ButterflyTeleport',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2,3],       # 0=S_A(\u03c8), 1=P_A\u2010idler, 2=P_C\u2010idler, 3=S_C(\u03c6)\n  'num_anc': 6,                       # six detectors\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,3],              # flying photons into network\n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # detectors D0\u2013D5\n  'out_nodes': [],                    # memories are offline at D and B\n  'target_quantum': ['110000','001100'],  \n    # e.g. patterns corresponding to XOR of two Bell\u2010measure outcomes\n  'removed_connections': [],          # full connectivity for optimization\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNo cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, single-photon transducers, and post\u2010selected heralding.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s butterfly network-coded joint measurement. A third photonic qubit (the control) determines in superposition whether the teleportation A\u2192B happens before B\u2192A or vice versa\u2014no dynamic switching is used.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Node A: superconducting qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A is transduced to a photonic qubit by single\u2010photon source S_A.  \n2. Node B: superconducting qubit \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B is likewise transduced by S_B.  \n3. Two local Bell\u2010pair sources P_A at A and P_B at B each emit a photon pair: one photon stays as the memory at the originating node; the idler photons P_Aid and P_Bid travel to the central station.  \n4. A control single\u2010photon source S_C prepares a flying photonic qubit in |+\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. Its two spatial modes route which of the two Bell\u2010measurements (the A\u2010measure on {S_A,P_Aid} or the B\u2010measure on {S_B,P_Bid}) occurs first in the interferometer.  \n5. All five flying photons (S_C, S_A, S_B, P_Aid, P_Bid) enter a fixed 5-port linear\u2010optics network of beam splitters and phase shifters. Five photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2026D4 record click patterns.  \n6. Two distinct two\u2010click patterns, each correlated with a control\u2010photon outcome, herald the successful quantum SWITCH:  \n   \u2013 If detectors D0+D1 click, the network has enacted \u201cA\u2010then\u2010B\u201d teleportation, yielding \u03c6 at A\u2019s memory and \u03c8 at B\u2019s memory.  \n   \u2013 If detectors D2+D3 click, it enacted \u201cB\u2010then\u2010A,\u201d yielding \u03c6 at A\u2019s memory and \u03c8 at B\u2019s memory in the opposite order.  \nBecause the control qubit was |+\u27e9, the overall process is a coherent superposition of both orders\u2014an indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order teleportation.\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N chained channels under indefinite order by adding more Bell sources and enlarging the interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use different control\u2010photon encodings to superpose arbitrary sequences of network operations.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum\u2010SWITCH of two teleportation channels between superconducting nodes A\u2194B via photonic control qubit',\n  'foldername': 'TeleportSwitch_QSWITCH',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # 0=S_C (control), 1=S_A (\u03c8), 2=S_B (\u03c6)\n  'amp_sources':       [],  \n  'pair_sources': [3,4],             # 3=P_A, 4=P_B\n  'num_anc': 5,                      # five detectors at the interferometer\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,5,6],           # flying: control (0), \u03c8 (1), \u03c6 (2), P_Aid(5), P_Bid(6)\n  'out_nodes': [7,8],                # memories: P_A-sig(7) at A, P_B-sig(8) at B\n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3,4],      # detectors D0\u2026D4\n  'target_quantum': ['11000','00110'],  \n     # e.g. clicks D0+D1 ('11000') = \u201cA then B\u201d; In one heralded run, the unknown states \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A, \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B, and \u2223\u03c7\u27e9_C are simultaneously transduced into three photonic qubits via transducers (single_emitters). An ancillary photon\u2010pair source provides two extra photons for the linear\u2010optics network. All five photons enter a fixed interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters) and are measured by four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. A specific two\u2010click heralding pattern signals successful implementation of the Fredkin truth table: if A\u2019s control bit is 0, B and C remain unchanged; if it is 1, their states are swapped. Upon heralding, the photonic outputs are mapped back to the superconducting memories at A, B, and C.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Post\u2010selected Fredkin (controlled\u2010SWAP) between three superconducting qubits via transduction & LOQC',\n  'foldername': 'Fredkin_FF',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # A flying control photonic qubit coherently superposes the order in which the teleportation A\u2192B and B\u2192A occur\u2014no dynamic elements, only post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Node A: unknown qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A is transduced into a photonic qubit by single\u2010photon source S_A.  \n2. Node B: unknown qubit state \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B is transduced by single\u2010photon source S_B.  \n3. Each node hosts a Bell\u2010pair source P_A at A and P_B at B. One photon of each pair remains stored locally as the memory; the other (idler) travels to the central station.  \n4. A control single\u2010photon source S_C prepares |+\u27e9=(|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. Depending on its spatial mode, the interferometer enacts either the A-then-B teleportation sequence or the B-then-A sequence.  \n5. The five flying photons (control, S_A, S_B, P_A-idler, P_B-idler) enter a fixed five-port beam-splitter network. Five photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record the herald.  \n6. Two distinct two-click patterns\u2014e.g. D0&D1 (\u201cA then B\u201d) or D2&D3 (\u201cB then A\u201d)\u2014herald successful teleportation in the respective order. Because the control qubit was |+\u27e9, the overall process coherently superposes both orders, realizing an indefinite causal order of two teleportation channels. After heralding, classical feed-forward applies Pauli corrections on A\u2019s and B\u2019s stored photons, completing both teleports.\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N-channel quantum SWITCHes by adding more Bell sources and enlarging the static interferometer.  \n\u2022 Explore superpositions of arbitrary network\u2010operation orders or embed the control qubit within higher-dimensional encodings.\n\nPytheus-style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum-SWITCH of two teleportation channels between superconducting nodes A\u2194B via flying control qubit',\n  'foldername': 'TeleportSwitch_QSWITCH',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],        # 0=S_C (control), 1=S_A (\u03c8), 2=S_B (\u03c6)\n  'pair_sources':    [3,4],          # 3=P_A, 4=P_B\n  'num_anc':         5,              # five detectors D0\u2026D4\n  'in_nodes':        [0,1,2,5,6],     # flying: control(0), \u03c8(1), \u03c6(2), P_A\u2010idler(5), P_B\u2010idler(6)\n  'heralding_out':   [0,1,2,3,4],     # detectors register herald patterns\n  'out_nodes':       [],             # memories at A/B are offline\n  'target_quantum':  ['11000','00110'], \n     # '11000' = D0&D1 click \u21d2 \u201cA\u2192B then B\u2192A\u201d;  \n     # '00110' = D2&D3 click \u21d2 \u201cB\u2192A then A\u2192B\u201d\n  'removed_connections': [],         # full connectivity\n  'thresholds':       [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer':        'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':        'cr',\n  'samples':          20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNo cavities or feedback loops\u2014only single\u2010photon transducers, probabilistic pair sources, a static linear\u2010optics network, and post-selected heralding.     "output": "Explanation:\nWe propose to implement an \u201cindefinite\u2010order teleportation\u201d channel (the quantum SWITCH of two teleportation links) between two remote superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A and B, using quantum transduction into flying photons and one static linear\u2010optics station. A control photonic qubit coherently superposes the order in which the teleportation A\u2192B or B\u2192A takes place\u2014no dynamic switches or feedback loops, only post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Node A\u2019s unknown qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 is mapped by a quantum transducer (single\u2010photon source S_A) into a photonic qubit.  \n2. Node B\u2019s unknown qubit \u2223\u03d5\u27e9_b is similarly transduced via S_B.  \n3. Each node hosts a Bell\u2010pair source (probabilistic photon\u2010pair source P_A at A, P_B at B). One photon of each pair remains stored locally as the memory; the other (\u201cidler\u201d) is sent to the central station.  \n4. A control photon in state |+\u27e9=(|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 from source S_C enters alongside the four \u201cteleportation\u201d photons. Depending on its spatial mode, the static interferometer implements either the sequence (A\u2010then\u2010B teleportation) or (B\u2010then\u2010A).  \n5. All five flying photons (control, S_A, S_B, P_A\u2010idler, P_B\u2010idler) pass through a fixed five\u2010port beam\u2010splitter + phase\u2010shifter network. Five photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors record which two detectors click.  \n6. Two distinct click\u2013patterns herald success:  \n   \u2022 D0+D1 clicks \u21d2 \u201cA\u2192B then B\u2192A\u201d executed; memories hold \u2223\u03d5\u27e9 at A and \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 at B.  \n   \u2022 D2+D3 clicks \u21d2 \u201cB\u2192A then A\u2192B\u201d; memories likewise updated but in the opposite order.  \nBecause the control photon was |+\u27e9, the entire operation is a coherent superposition of both causal orders. Classical Pauli corrections (outside Pytheus) complete each teleportation.\n\nGeneralizations:\n\u2022 Extend to N\u2010link SWITCHes by adding N Bell sources and enlarging the interferometer.  \n\u2022 Embed higher\u2010dimensional control qudits to superpose richer network\u2010operation sequences.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Indefinite\u2010order teleportation channel (quantum\u2010SWITCH) between superconducting nodes A\u2194B via transduction & LOQC',\n  'foldername': 'TeleportQSwitch',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # 0=S_C (control), 1=S_A (\u03c8), 2=S_B (\u03d5)\n  'pair_sources':    [3,4],          # 3=P_A idler, 4=P_B idler\n  'num_anc':         5,              # five photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\n  'in_nodes':        [0,1,2,5,6],     # flying: control(0), \u03c8(1), \u03d5(2), P_A-idler(5), P_B-idler(6)\n  'heralding_out':   [0,1,2,3,4],     # detectors D0\u2026D4\n  'out_nodes':       [],             # memories (signal photons) at A & B are offline\n  'target_quantum':  ['11000','00110'],  \n     # '11000' = D0&D1 click \u21d2 A\u2192B then B\u2192A  \n     # '00110' = D2&D3 click \u21d2 B\u2192A then A\u2192B\n  'removed_connections': [],         # all sources may connect to all detectors\n  'thresholds':       [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer':        'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':        'cr',\n  'samples':          20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy this is novel:\n\u2013 Implements a genuinely new network primitive\u2014the quantum\u2010SWITCH of two teleportation channels\u2014rather than mere pairwise entanglement swapping or fixed\u2010order teleportation.  \n\u2013 Combines superconducting\u2010qubit transduction with linear\u2010optics measurements in a static interferometer to achieve indefinite causal order.\n\nWhy this is Pytheus\u2010feasible:\n\u2013 Uses only single\u2010photon and probabilistic pair sources plus beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n\u2013 No cavities, resonators, dynamic feedback, or active switching elements are required, fitting exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. An unknown superconducting\u2010qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 on A is converted into a photonic qubit (source S_A). Nodes B and C each host an optical Bell\u2010pair source (S_B, S_C); one photon from each pair is held in the local memory as the eventual teleported state, while the other two photons (idler photons) are sent to the central station. All three flying photons (from S_A, S_B, S_C) enter a three\u2010input linear\u2010optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters) and are detected by three photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Two distinct click patterns, P_B or P_C, herald the successful teleportation to B or C, respectively. No active routing or feedback is needed\u2014conditional on P_B the qubit appears in B\u2019s memory, on P_C it appears in C\u2019s memory.  \n\nVisualization:  \nsources:   [S_A]   [S_B_idler]   [S_C_idler]  \nnetwork:   [static 3-input interferometer]  \ndetectors: [D0][D1][D2]  \nmemories:  [qubit B]      [qubit C]  \n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:  \n{  \n  'description': 'Teleportation router: A\u2192{B or C} via transducers & static linear optics',  \n  'foldername': 'TeleportationRouter',  \n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # 0=S_A (\u03c8), 1=S_B_idler, 2=S_C_idler  \n  'num_anc': 3,                     # three detectors in the router  \n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2],              # inputs to the interferometer  \n  'out_nodes': [],                  # memories are off-line at B/C  \n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2],         # detectors record herald patterns  \n  'target_quantum': ['100','010','001'],  \n      # Interpret '100' or '010' or '001' as different routing outcomes; we pick two patterns:\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],  \n  'removed_connections': [],        # allow all source-to-detector paths  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nGeneralization:  \n\u2022 Extend to N receivers by adding N Bell sources and an (N+1)-port interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use delayed-choice routing by post-selecting which heralding pattern to accept.  \n\nNo cavities, no feedback loops\u2014only static linear optics, single-photon emitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel, you must move beyond the standard Bell-swap router. Input:  \nExplanation:  \nWe propose a \u201ccyclic teleportation channel\u201d (a 3-cycle SWAP gate) between three superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A, B, and C, mediated by quantum transduction and a single static linear\u2010optics station. In one heralded run, A\u2019s state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 is teleported to B, B\u2019s state \u2223\u03d5\u27e9\u2082 to C, and C\u2019s state \u2223\u03c7\u27e9\u2083 back to A, all simultaneously and without dynamic routing.  \n\nProtocol outline:  \n1. At each node X\u2208{A,B,C}, the superconducting qubit in unknown state \u2223\u03be\u27e9\u2093 is mapped to a photonic qubit via a quantum transducer (single\u2010photon source S\u2093).  \n2. Each node also hosts a local Bell\u2010pair source (probabilistic photon\u2010pair source P\u2093): one photon remains stored as the target memory at X; its partner (the idler) is sent to the central station.  \n3. The six flying photons (three from transducers S_A,S_B,S_C; three idlers from P_A,P_B,P_C) enter a fixed six\u2010input linear\u2010optics network (beam splitters + phase shifters) and are measured by six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n4. Two sender nodes, A and C, each hold an unknown superconducting\u2010qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A and \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C to be simultaneously teleported across the network to receivers D and B, respectively, even though the network\u2019s optical\u2010fiber layout is the minimal \u201cbutterfly\u201d shape.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Nodes A and C each transduce their unknown qubit (\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A, \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C) into a photonic qubit via a single\u2010photon source (S_A, S_C).  \n2. At A and C, independent Bell\u2010pair sources (P_A, P_C) generate a second photon each; those idler photons are also sent to the central station, while their partner photons remain stored locally as the target memories at D and B, respectively.  \n3. A total of four flying photons (two from the unknown\u2010state transducers, two idlers from Bell sources) enter a central static 4\u2010input linear\u2010optics network that realizes two overlapping Bell\u2010measurements in the butterfly configuration: the \u201cXOR\u2010node\u201d of the butterfly combines one output of A\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement with one output of C\u2019s, implementing the network coding.  \n4. Six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (two per Bell\u2010measurement) record four\u2010click heralding patterns that correspond to successful network\u2010coded teleportation. Conditioned on the specific click pattern, \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A appears in node D\u2019s memory and \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_C appears in node B\u2019s memory.  \n5. Classical feed\u2010forward (outside Pytheus) applies Pauli corrections on the stored photons at B and D, completing the teleportation.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources: [S_A] [P_A\u2010idler] [P_C\u2010idler] [S_C]  \nnetwork: [4-input \u201cbutterfly\u201d interferometer implementing two Bell+XOR nodes]  \ndetectors: [D0][D1][D2][D3][D4][D5]  \nmemories: [qubit D]    [qubit B]  \n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to larger network\u2010coding graphs (e.g. two\u2010source multi\u2010receiver multicast channels).  \n\u2022 Replace the static XOR node by programmable interferometers to realize different network functions.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum butterfly network\u2010coding teleportation between nodes A,C \u2192 D,B via transducers & static linear optics',\n  'foldername': 'ButterflyTeleport',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2,3],       # 0=S_A(\u03c8), 1=P_A\u2010idler, 2=P_C\u2010idler, 3=S_C(\u03c6)\n  'num_anc': 6,                       # six detectors\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,3],              # flying photons into network\n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # detectors D0\u2013D5\n  'out_nodes': [],                    # memories are offline at D and B\n  'target_quantum': ['110000','001100'],  \n    # e.g. patterns corresponding to XOR of two Bell\u2010measure outcomes\n  'removed_connections': [],          # full connectivity for optimization\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNo cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, single-photon transducers, and post\u2010selected heralding.\n\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s butterfly network-coded joint measurement. This realizes indefinite causal order of two teleportation operations in one static linear\u2010optics network.\nStep 2: Compare/obstacles:\n  a) Already known multi\u2010swap examples.\n  b) Similar to earlier \u201crouter\u201d proposals.\n  c) Novel network primitive (quantum SWITCH) on teleportation channels; Pytheus can optimize a fixed multiport interferometer to enact a control\u2010qubit\u2013dependent mixing of two Bell\u2010measurements, with no dynamic feedback.\nStep 3: Choose (c).\nStep 4: Novelty: It is the first Pytheus\u2010style experiment to implement a quantum SWITCH of two teleportation channels between remote superconducting nodes, creating an indefinite causal order of network operations rather than a fixed swap or router.  \nStep 5: Feasibility: Only single\u2010photon (transducer) sources, two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, one single\u2010photon control source, a static 5-input linear\u2010optics interferometer, and 5 photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. No cavities, no active switching or feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExplanation:\nWe propose to implement an \u201cindefinite\u2010order teleportation switch\u201d (quantum SWITCH) between two superconducting\u2010qubit nodes A and B, mediated by quantum transduction and one static linear\u2010optics station. A third photonic qubit (the control) determines in superposition whether the teleportation A\u2192B happens before B\u2192A or vice versa\u2014no dynamic switching is used.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Node A: superconducting qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A is transduced to a photonic qubit by single\u2010photon source S_A.  \n2. Node B: superconducting qubit \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B is likewise transduced by S_B.  \n3. Two local Bell\u2010pair sources P_A at A and P_B at B each emit a photon pair: one photon stays as the memory at the originating node; the idler photons P_Aid and P_Bid travel to the central station.  \n4. A control single\u2010photon source S_C prepares a flying photonic qubit in |+\u27e9 = (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. Its two spatial modes route which of the two Bell\u2010measurements (the A\u2010measure on {S_A,P_Aid} or the B\u2010measure on {S_B,P_Bid}) occurs first in the interferometer.  \n5. All five flying photons (S_C, S_A, S_B, P_Aid, P_Bid) enter a fixed 5-port linear\u2010optics network of beam splitters and phase shifters. Five photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2026D4 record click patterns.  \n6. Two distinct two\u2010click patterns, each correlated with a control\u2010photon outcome, herald the successful quantum SWITCH:  \n   \u2013 If detectors D0+D1 click, the network has enacted \u201cA\u2010then\u2010B\u201d teleportation, yielding \u03c6 at A\u2019s memory and \u03c8 at B\u2019s memory.  \n   \u2013 If detectors D2+D3 click, it enacted \u201cB\u2010then\u2010A,\u201d yielding \u03c6 at A\u2019s memory and \u03c8 at B\u2019s memory in the opposite order.  \nBecause the control qubit was |+\u27e9, the overall process is a coherent superposition of both orders\u2014an indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order teleportation.\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Extend to N chained channels under indefinite order by adding more Bell sources and enlarging the interferometer.  \n\u2022 Use different control\u2010photon encodings to superpose arbitrary sequences of network operations.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum\u2010SWITCH of two teleportation channels between superconducting nodes A\u2194B via photonic control qubit',\n  'foldername': 'TeleportSwitch_QSWITCH',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1,2],       # 0=S_C (control), 1=S_A (\u03c8), 2=S_B (\u03c6)\n  'amp_sources':       [],  \n  'pair_sources': [3,4],             # 3=P_A, 4=P_B\n  'num_anc': 5,                      # five detectors at the interferometer\n  'in_nodes': [0,1,2,5,6],           # flying: control (0), \u03c8 (1), \u03c6 (2), P_Aid(5), P_Bid(6)\n  'out_nodes': [7,8],                # memories: P_A-sig(7) at A, P_B-sig(8) at B\n  'heralding_out': [0,1,2,3,4],      # detectors D0\u2026D4\n  'target_quantum': ['11000','00110'],  \n     # e.g. clicks D0+D1 ('11000') = \u201cA then B\u201d; D2+D3 ('00110') = \u201cB then A\u201d\n  'removed_connections': [],         # full interferometer connectivity\n  'thresholds': [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNo cavities or dynamic feedback\u2014only static linear optics, single\u2010photon (transducer) sources, probabilistic pair sources, and post\u2010selected heralding. A flying control photonic qubit coherently superposes the order in which the teleportation A\u2192B and B\u2192A occur\u2014no dynamic elements, only post\u2010selected heralding.\n\nProtocol outline:\n1. Node A: unknown qubit state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A is transduced into a photonic qubit by single\u2010photon source S_A.  \n2.     "output": "We propose a \u201cRemote\u2010SWAP\u2010Test\u201d network: a linear\u2010optics measurement that projects two unknown superconducting\u2010qubit states onto their symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspace, entirely via quantum transduction and post\u2010selected photonic interference.  This realizes a fundamental quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014nonlocal SWAP\u2010test\u2014rather than generating a specific entangled state.\n\n1) Nodes A and B each hold an unknown superconducting qubit \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A, \u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B.  Each is transduced into a single photonic qubit via a dedicated transducer (treated as single\u2010photon emitters S_A and S_B).  \n2) A single Bell\u2010pair source P supplies two ancilla photons whose one half (\u201cancilla\u2010idler\u201d) is injected into the interferometer and whose partner photons remain at C as a classical \u201cyes/no\u201d register (or simply discarded).  \n3) The four flying photons (S_A, S_B, P_idler1, P_idler2) enter a static 4\u2010port linear\u2010optics network (beam splitters + phase shifts) optimized to enact the SWAP\u2010test circuit: symmetric inputs bunch vs. antisymmetric inputs antibunch.  \n4) Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2026D3 record the click pattern.  Two distinct click\u2010patterns herald the two possible outcomes of the SWAP test:  \n   \u2022 \u201cSame\u201d (symmetric subspace) pattern \u2192 detectors {D0,D1} click  \n   \u2022 \u201cDifferent\u201d (antisymmetric subspace) pattern \u2192 detectors {D2,D3} click  \n5) Conditioning on which pattern fires gives a nonlocal SWAP\u2010test result on \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 and \u2223\u03c6\u27e9, which can steer subsequent network operations (e.g. entanglement purification, state\u2010comparison decision, or error\u2010flagging) at node C.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nsources:   [S_A]   [S_B]   [P_idler1]   [P_idler2]  \nnetwork:   [static 4\u2010port interferometer]  \ndetectors: [D0][D1][D2][D3]  \ntakes \u2192 nonlocal SWAP\u2010test outcome.\n\nGeneralizations:\n\u2022 Replace the single Bell\u2010pair ancilla with multiple ancilla photons to increase confidence (multi\u2010round SWAP tests).  \n\u2022 Embed the test outcome into a larger repeater network for automatic error detection across segments.  \n\u2022 Extend to high\u2010dimensional SWAP tests by using multi\u2010rail encodings in the same interferometer.\n\nPytheus\u2010style Config Skeleton:\n{\n  'description':   'Remote SWAP\u2010test of two superconducting qubits via transduction & LOQC',\n  'foldername':    'RemoteSwapTest',\n  'single_emitters': [0,1],           # 0=S_A(\u03c8), 1=S_B(\u03c6)\n  'pair_sources':   [2],              # 2=Bell\u2010pair ancilla\n  'num_anc':        4,                # detectors D0\u2013D3\n  'in_nodes':       [0,1,3,4],        # flying: \u03c8(0), \u03c6(1), ancilla idlers(3,4)\n  'heralding_out':  [0,1,2,3],        # D0\u2013D3 record clicks\n  'out_nodes':      [],               # memories at A/B hold the original qubits\n  'target_quantum': ['1100','0011'],  # '1100' \u2194 symmetric; '0011' \u2194 antisymmetric\n  'removed_connections': [],          # full connectivity for the interferometer\n  'thresholds':     [0.3,0.1],\n  'optimizer':      'L-BFGS-B',\n  'loss_func':      'cr',\n  'samples':        20,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel?\n\u2022 No prior Pytheus experiment has realized a nonlocal SWAP\u2010test measuring the overlap between two unknown qubits at remote nodes.  \n\u2022 It introduces a genuinely new network primitive\u2014distributed state\u2010comparison\u2014rather than state generation or simple swapping/teleportation.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible?\n\u2022 Only uses single\u2010photon transducers and a single Bell\u2010pair source (all abstractly defined), a static linear\u2010optics network, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n\u2022 No cavities or realtime feedback\u2014pure post\u2010selection on two distinct click\u2010patterns.  \n\u2022 Pytheus can optimize the static interferometer layout to maximize the success probability of the SWAP\u2010test measurement.\n\nThis \u201cRemote SWAP\u2010Test\u201d opens the door to quantum\u2010network\u2010coding protocols with built\u2010in error\u2010detection, multi\u2010party consensus tests, and hybrid repeater designs that actively compare and filter qubit quality across distant nodes."
}

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task.
